key_insight: A hybrid representation that combines a lightweight triangle mesh with anisotropic 3D Gaussians enables photorealistic head avatars that are both memory- and render-efficient enough for mobile devices.
problem_solved: How to achieve high-fidelity, view-consistent head avatars from multi-view images while keeping memory use and rendering cost low enough for real-time/mobile deployment.
method: Build a compact triangle mesh to represent smooth surface regions (e.g., skin) and place anisotropic 3D Gaussians to capture fine, view-dependent and volumetric detail (e.g., hair, eyelashes, complex shading).
Fit the hybrid representation to multi-view imagery, optimizing Gaussian parameters and mesh appearance to reproduce photorealistic renderings.
Render efficiently on mobile by leveraging the mesh for rasterization and the Gaussians for compact splatting/blending, minimizing memory and compute overhead.
impact: GPiCA makes it practical to run photorealistic avatar rendering on resource-constrained devices, enabling real-time telepresence, AR/VR avatars, and lightweight 3D content pipelines for ML and graphics applications.
visual_elements: Side-by-side visual comparison: ground-truth photo vs GPiCA render to show photorealism.
Hybrid representation diagram: mesh regions highlighted plus colored anisotropic Gaussian blobs showing where each component contributes.
Pipeline flowchart: multi-view input → fitting/optimization → hybrid model → mobile-optimized renderer.
Performance chart: memory footprint and runtime (FPS) vs visual quality for GPiCA and baseline approaches on mobile hardware.
paper_title: Gaussian Pixel Codec Avatars: A Hybrid Representation for Efficient Rendering
paper_authors: Divam Gupta, Anuj Pahuja, Nemanja Bartolovic, Tomas Simon, Forrest Iandola
